Text:
My Day by Eleanor Roosevelt

Text Size: Small Text Normal Text Large Text Larger Text

EUGENE, Ore.—I was very much interested to read in a current magazine the appraisal made of the Advisory Council of the Democratic party, which is composed of the Executive Committee members of the Democratic National Committee with Chairman Paul Butler and of various and sundry prominent Democrats, governors of states, Senators and Representatives.

The Democratic leaders in Congress, Majority Leader Sen. Lyndon Johnson and House Speaker Sam Rayburn, stayed aloof at the Advisory Council's inception, but I think they must realize by now that through its public actions and statements this group is giving some real leadership to the Democratic rank and file in the country.

Everyone may not agree with everything the council says. In fact, within the council there are differences of opinion. But this is one place where party strength is not dominated by seniority, and those who represent the parts of the country where Democratic gains have been made feel that here they can freely express themselves.

The council is doing all it can to promote the achievement of platform promises, and what effect it will have on the choice for President at the next national convention is still problematical.

I had a most delightful luncheon and an informative session with the class in journalism at Ricks College, a Mormon school, in Rexburg, Idaho. The authorities are planning to move this college to Idaho Falls and to institute a program of expansion. At Rexburg there is room for only 900 students, and the hope is that the new school will have an enrollment of 3,000.

The institution is supported entirely by the Church of the Latter Day Saints, or Mormons as they are commonly called.

Since members of this religious organization go out as missionaries all over the world, it is interesting to find what foreign contacts will do for them. The journalism professor told me he had gone to Mexico and he felt that having lived with the people there for several years it would be impossible to go to war with them. He is convinced that the program that sends out young Mormon students to all parts of the world has made them more valuable in preserving the peace of the world.

This, of course, is what we hope our international educational exchange of students will do through the Fulbright law. Yet, some of our Representatives and Senators are all for cutting down on these exchanges. They feel it would be one of the good ways to save money.

But it makes no sense to me to pay out money to keep a balance of armaments throughout the world, hoping that strength will discourage an enemy attack, and then not to go on paying for a program that will help to prepare us to live in peace.

More than once I have been asked by young college journalism students here if it is true that our businesses would suffer drastically if our economy had to convert rapidly into a full peacetime economy. They want to know why these interests seem to do everything in their power to keep us not only preparing for war but almost constantly give us the feeling that war is imminent.

I was amazed to find the feeling so prevalent that we are not intelligent enough to operate our economic existence without a great expenditure for war preparation.

If it were true that we are not capable of maintaining a high peacetime economy I think it would be entirely understandable if those nations throughout the world that need economic help were to turn on us and despise us. With all the needs there are in the world our ingenuity should be able to make that transition to peacetime production without an economic catastrophe.

### **Scene Concept: "The Diplomatic Press Hub"**  

#### **1. Overall Scene Theme and Core Concept**  
A bustling **political press office** during a high-stakes international conference, where journalists, diplomats, and aides collaborate under tight deadlines. The space is a nexus of **information, negotiation, and crisis management**, requiring multi-agent coordination to handle sensitive documents, manage communication devices, and respond to rapidly unfolding events.  

**Why Multi-Agent?**  
- **Heavy logistics:** Some items (broadcast equipment, secure document crates) require multiple people to move.  
- **Information asymmetry:** Different agents have access to different documents, requiring collaboration to piece together the full picture.  
- **Time pressure:** Urgent tasks (printing press malfunctions, last-minute script edits) demand parallel workstreams.  

---  

### **2. Spatial Layout and Area Descriptions**  
The **Press Hub** is a converted **grand hotel ballroom**, repurposed with modular workstations. Key areas:  

1. **Main Newsroom Floor** – Open-plan with clustered desks, strewn with papers, typewriters, and telephones.  
2. **Secure Document Prep Room** – A locked side chamber where classified briefings are compiled.  
3. **Broadcast Studio Corner** – A makeshift recording booth with microphones and reel-to-reel machines.  
4. **Printing & Duplication Station** – Industrial mimeographs and a cranky printing press.  
5. **Diplomats’ Lounge** – A quieter area with couches, a coffee urn, and a wall-mounted world map.  

---  

### **3. Detailed Area-by-Area Inventory**  

#### **A. Main Newsroom Floor**  
**a. Anchor Furniture & Installations:**  
- **Central Assignment Board:** A large chalkboard listing reporter assignments, with half-erased updates in red and blue chalk.  
- **Heavy Oak Dispatch Desk:** A 3m-long desk with pigeonholes labeled “URGENT,” “HOLD,” and “FOREIGN CORRESPONDENTS.”  

**b. Key Interactive & Task-Relevant Objects:**  
- **Encrypted Teletype Machine (Broken):** A Cold War-era device flashing “ERROR 47” on its small green screen. Requires a technician’s manual (stored in the Printing Station).  
- **Sealed Diplomatic Pouch:** A reinforced leather satchel (weight: 12kg) with a combination lock (code written on a notecard in the Document Prep Room).  

**c. Functional Ambient Objects:**  
- **Overloaded Bulletin Board:** Pinned with press badges, telegrams, and a curling “NO SMOKING” sign.  
- **Coffee Cart:** Half-full glass percolator (still hot), stack of chipped porcelain cups, sugar bowl with a sticky spoon.  

**d. Background & Decorative Objects:**  
- **Framed Propaganda Posters:** “UNITY FOR PEACE” in faded colors, slightly askew.  
- **Abandoned Fedora:** Perched on a coat rack, with a train ticket stub tucked in the band.  

---  

#### **B. Secure Document Prep Room**  
**a. Anchor Furniture & Installations:**  
- **Steel Filing Cabinet (Locked):** Requires a key held by the lead editor (who is currently in the Diplomats’ Lounge).  
- **Large Light Table:** For reviewing photographic negatives, still scattered with undeveloped film strips.  

**b. Key Interactive & Task-Relevant Objects:**  
- **Red-Bound Dossier:** Marked “CONFIDENTIAL – ECONOMIC IMPACT ASSESSMENT,” partially obscured under a stack of blank treaty forms.  
- **Microfilm Reader (Powered Off):** Dusty, with a jammed film reel inside.  

**c. Functional Ambient Objects:**  
- **Wall Clock:** Ticking loudly, 10 minutes behind real time.  
- **Paper Shredder:** Overfilled bin, a torn corner of a sensitive memo caught in the mechanism.  

**d. Background & Decorative Objects:**  
- **Old Diplomatic Gifts:** A decorative but non-functional samovar (tarnished), a plaque from a 1956 summit.  

---  

#### **C. Broadcast Studio Corner**  
**a. Anchor Furniture & Installations:**  
- **Broadcast Console:** A steel panel with toggle switches (some loose), a large “ON AIR” bulb (flickering).  

**b. Key Interactive & Task-Relevant Objects:**  
- **Reel-to-Reel Recorder (Out of Tape):** Empty take-up reel; new tapes stored in a locked drawer (key missing).  
- **Script Revision Pages:** Handwritten edits on onion-skin paper, scattered across the floor.  

**c. Functional Ambient Objects:**  
- **Headphones:** One ear cup dangling, cord frayed near the plug.  
- **Glass Soundproofing Panels:** Finger-smudged, one cracked at the corner.  

**d. Background & Decorative Objects:**  
- **Fake Plant:** Dusty plastic fern in the corner.  
- **Outdated Schedule:** A typed program from yesterday’s broadcast still taped to the wall.  

---  

### **4. Scene Affordances and Embedded Potential**  

#### **Collaborative Transportation Affordances:**  
- **The Broadcast Console (Weight: 150kg)** – Too heavy for one person; requires coordination to reposition for a live feed.  
- **Sealed Diplomatic Pouch (12kg, bulky)** – Must be carried carefully by two agents to avoid triggering a hidden pressure-sensitive alarm.  

#### **Reasoning & Tool-Use Affordances:**  
- **Attribute-Based Reasoning:** Among five nearly identical **red-bound dossiers**, only one has a **small blue UN seal** and **water damage on page 17**—critical for verifying authenticity.  
- **Compound Reasoning:** The **encrypted teletype (broken)** requires:  
  1. Finding the **technician’s manual** (in Printing Station, under a stack of misprinted bulletins).  
  2. Using a **small flathead screwdriver** (left on the Dispatch Desk) to open the rear panel.  

#### **Atmospheric Distractors:**  
- A **decorative blue glass paperweight** on the editor’s desk could be mistaken for the **UN-sealed dossier** at a glance.  
- The **fake plant** near the broadcast console obscures a **partially hidden emergency shutoff switch**.  

---  

**Final Notes:**  
This scene is a **living puzzle box**—every object has a purpose, every state change (broken, locked, misplaced) demands collaboration. The density of interactive and ambient elements ensures agents must **navigate clutter, filter signal from noise, and work together under pressure**—just like real-world diplomacy.
